H0.text: A planet moves in a regular path around the Sun.

H1.text: A constellation is a group of stars that moves in a regular path around the Sun.

H2.text: A meteor moves in a regular path around the Sun.

H3.text: A star moves in a regular path around the Sun.

A4.text: No planet's orbit is perfectly circular, and hence the distance of each from the host star varies over the course of its year.

A5.text: At least one exoplanet, WASP-17b, has been found to orbit in the opposite direction to its star's rotation.

A6.text: Bodies following closed orbits repeat their paths with a certain time called the period.

A7.text: The orbit of a planet around the Sun is an ellipse, with the Sun in one of the focal points of that ellipse.

A8.text: NOAA page on Climate Forcing Data includes (calculated) data on Earth orbit variations over the last 50 million years and for the coming 20 million years

A11.text: The latter have elliptical orbits that are inclined to the plane of the galaxy.
